title: The Brutal Truth: 'How You Do Anything is How You Do Everything" #realitycheck  #BrutallyHonest
caption: false

channel_info.title: Robbie Kramer
channel_info.description:
I'm Robbie Kramer 🎙Host of The Inner Confidence Podcast & Founder of Inner Confidence, Inc.

I lived an exhilarating single life filled with adventures and lessons, and ultimately achieved what I had always aspired to – finding an amazing, feminine, and loving wife. 

I believe my experiences provide a rare balance of wild freedom and committed love, equipping me with the insights to help you navigate the complexities of dating and relationships in today's world. Let me guide you to embrace your desires, improve your social prowess, and ultimately attract the partner who aligns with your highest aspirations.

You won’t find any fluffy, new-age, or cringy stuff here, just tested, proven and actionable advice that yields results.

Apply to join our exclusive Inner Confidence Community of ambitious men who are actively working together to achieve their goals faster   ► https://innerconfidence.com/community

You can email me at robbie@innerconfidence.com with any questions or comments.

transcription: {"text": "One of my gurus, I guess you could say, he passed away. So he had this group in Santa Monica where he would teach basically like embodiment work. Oh, okay. The intro to his work is you meet him at the Santa Monica boardwalk. He videotapes you renting rollerblades and then you rollerblade with him while he's videotaping the whole thing. Then you got in his car and then he gives you feedback on how you are in life based on the video. And he tells you things like, well, you're rollerblading and you're staring at the ground the whole time. You never once look out to the horizon. You have no vision for your life. You are a certain way. And I know this about you because this whole premise was how you do anything. It's how you do everything, which I tend to agree with in a lot of ways. And then he also ran this group where we'd do all these movement exercises, you know, and he'd have people like shaking their hands and saying like, you're signaling to get away from me. You're saying, gimme, gimme, gimme. Like it was weird, but it was interesting. And you learned a lot about yourself and it was a safe space where people could be very honest and extremely judgmental, but forward about it. So you'd get feedback that you would never hear. It's like your workshops. I adopted a lot of the practice from him, of course. One feels so safe and you can say the meanest things ever, but it's all with love. Exactly.
